author: sky.cactus
content:
A. Miners don't use AWS, their external data bandwidth costs are crazy high.
B. Miners don't usually pick their peers aside from some hard coded ones.
C. Even if a miner only connected locally, that is fine because the block would propagate out.
D. Miners whose blocks aren't seen by the network fast enough get uncled, and they lose money.

author: sky.cactus
content: In most cases, the cost of outbound bandwidth is not a function of *where* you are sending to.  It is just a question of "are you sending data out" or not.

author: sky.cactus
content: If you are talking about block censorship attacks, this is a very real problem with Proof of Work that has no good solution (except Proof of Stake, which isn't even perfect but significantly better).

author: sky.cactus
content: If you aren't talking about block censorship, then miners still have an incentive to get blocks out to users because a group of miners mining blocks but not publishing them would not be providing a service to any users, and thus would be ignored by the rest of the network.

author: sky.cactus
content: Miners *have* to serve blocks externally in order to provide value to customers.

author: sky.cactus
content: Once those blocks are out there, anyone can propagate them.

author: sky.cactus
content: Unless you can partition some particular user entirely out of the P2P network, you can't effectively censor someone's access.

author: sky.cactus
content: Functionally, what this means is that as long as you have a *sufficient* number of altruistic actors in the network, everyone will *eventually* get every block.

author: sky.cactus
content: Requiring some small number of honest/altruistic nodes in a system is often a great design.  What is a bad design is requiring a *large portion* of nodes be honest/altruistic.

author: sky.cactus
content: In the case of a gossip network, you generally only need a small number of honest/altruistic nodes in order for the whole thing to stay live in the face of mostly profit seeking operators.

author: ghosts_in_the_code
content: can that be quantified? like how much $$ needs to be altruistically burned to keep the network running?

author: sky.cactus
content: Things like the Portal Network are trying to make it so operating a node altruistically is significantly cheaper.

author: sky.cactus
content: This is an interesting question, and I suspect not easy to answer sadly.  You would need to first figure out what percentage of the network it is "profitable" to be connected to.  Also, there are people who can profit off of end-users (arbitragers, frontrunners, etc.).  Plus there is the non-trivial cost of actually trying to figure out who is "worth" connecting to, vs just blanket connecting to as many people as possible (the naive, but very easy and cheap to implement strategy).

author: sky.cactus
content: Then once you have removed all of those things, you would be left with some subset of "unprofitable to connect to" nodes, and then you would need to calculate the cost of sending data to each of them.

author: jgm
content:
At the (eth2)  consensus layer  there is peer scoring.  If you try to run a node to receive blocks without making those blocks available to other nodes your peer score will be reduced and eventually they will disconnect and ban you.  Not a perfect system, of course, but a step in the right direction.

And in most situations today the cost of bandwidth for running a node that shares data is going to be a lot lower than the time cost of altering code so you receive but don't propagate blocks.  Bad actors can always try to freeload, but the effort required to do so will commonly make it counter-productive.

author: sky.cactus
content: Very big üëç on that second paragraph.  Defaults are *incredibly* powerful, especially when changing them requires engineering.

author: norswap
content: See here for the different flavors: https://www.notion.so/norswap/State-Expiry-Statelessness-in-Review-8d531abcc2984babb9bf76a44459e611#621e2a542e8c4bc683089e7955ce0d36

author: norswap
content:
essentially full/fast/snap do download the full blockchains
full runs all the transactions
fast does not (only validates the headers), gets a recent pivot and starts working from there
snap is sort of the same but the difference is in how they get the pivot/snapshot data
fast asks every node in the state tree (one roundtrip per node), whereas snap only asks for the leaves (which are send batched) and rebuilds the intermediate nodes itself

author: norswap
content: and then there's beam sync which just asks for witnesses on demand
